title: Tuesday, 1st October 2019
bodyHTML:
Blank canvas Good morning
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Welcome to Markets Live, where you can look forward to a packed hour analysing Greggs' trading update.

BE11:04am

Because, in the absence of anything else this morning, those seven paragraphs are what we got.

Blank canvas Where is everyone?
BE11:04am

And two of those are on menu and opening hours.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

Our Autumn menu is now available in our shops, and features exciting new additions to our hot sandwich range, including Chipotle Chilli Steak and Hot Peri Peri Chicken Baguettes. Our popular Spicy Chicken and Pepperoni Bake also makes a welcome return, alongside our Pumpkin Spice Latte.

Soundbuy Morning
MnM Buenos
BE11:05am

We are progressing trials to open a number of shops later into the evening, supported by an extended range of great value 'post-4pm' deals. These include our £2 pizza plus drink offer and a new hot menu meal deal, which is made up of any hot sandwich or chicken goujons plus potato wedges and a drink for just £4. We are encouraged by customer demand for our delivery service trials, and are developing the operational processes to service this channel.

Plato the Cook Morning. An inconsequential distraction will be very welcome
chad_john Ah! But they have competition. Fray Bentos have announced a Vegan pie.
BE11:05am

What depth of zen-like self loathing do you need to achieve before you can get on the outside of a Spicy Chicken and Pepperoni Bake?

VV75 morning
11:05 am
BE11:06am

Okay, so there are a few more things.

BE11:06am

UK Manufacturing PMI ....

VV75 but is it vegan?
CryptoWhipto Morning, any insight on the Panmure and Credit Suisse sell notes on Hargreaves Lansdown
chad_john @VV75 Yep.

John Rogers, architect of Sainsbury Bank and some other things that weren't massive failures, is off to WPP.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

CMA's levelled up on JD Sports' related party transaction

BE11:06am

Um ......... M&S is having a coffee morning "by invitation only"

BE11:07am

Er ......... ScS, the sofa shop that isn't DFS, has warned on the same things DFS warned on last week.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Oh, and Laura Kuenssberg gets her news from punter bulletin boards, which is a wee bit of a surprise.

BE11:07am

https://twitter.com/bbclaurak/status/1178916599438483458

undefined
11:08 am
BE11:08am

@CryptoWhipto: we'll get to HL.

den I went in to an SCS shop last week - the staff outnumbered me by 6-1
BE11:08am

But only after sausage rolls.

Soundbuy Greggs morphing into Wetherspoons' fare.......(except for the pint)
VV75 some comments on Ferguson please, if you have any.
nightingale20201 morning all
BE11:09am

Slowing LFL, not unexpectedly. But it can be argued that the shares were priced for upgrades.

Plato the Cook I suspect Laura’s reputation would not be so enhanced if she were not on the BBC
11:09 am
Greggs PLC (GRG:LSE): Last: 1,958, down 132 (-6.32%), High: 2,146, Low: 1,939, Volume: 501.80k
Soundbuy Laura Kuenssberg - has the makings of an evil market maker......
chad_john Ah I disagree, I think Laura K is excellent.
BE11:10am

Barclays has managed about 30 pars on the update, which is an achievement.

BE11:10am

Our view: Slowing 2 year LFL may disappoint momentum investors, but investment in business initiatives (delivery, digital, later day parts) continues and should help ensure premium rating remains in medium term.

Q3 trading update: LFL sales growth in the 13 weeks to 28th September were +7.4%. This compares with H1 LFLs of 10.5%, so the 1 year LFL has slowed. The 2 year LFL has also slowed, moving to 10.8%, down from 12.2% in H1, as illustrated in the table below. Comps toughen again in Q4, and the company has commented it expects LFLs to moderate again in Q4. This was inevitable at some point, and whilst the company’s guidance remains unchanged, this may encourage (remaining) momentum investors to look elsewhere. There have been 56 net new store openings so far this year, with “around 90” expected for the full year (previous guidance “around 100”).

IMP.GLD Grey on Credit Suisse if FT legal team allow? Grizzly stuff.
Soundbuy I'm warming to Laura.......not sure she reciprocates my feelings
11:11 am
BE11:11am

(@ROTR: Markets Live has no time whatsoever for Kuenssberg criticism. Take it to Twitter, if you must., but I'd rather you didn't do that either qf.)

BE11:12am

Want the conference call notes? Course you do.

Grouchmonkey Morning all
BE11:12am

Key points from the conference call – NLW already paid the same across all age groups, LFLs expected to slow slightly again in Q4:

· Exit rate for trading in the summer was c10% on a 2 year LFL, it’s actually been slightly better than this in Q3 (see above, 10.8%). May slip back further on a 2 year basis in Q4 – will have to see how that goes.

· Openings at 90 rather than 100 because some of the franchise partners have slipped back. Delay, not cancelled.

· Investment for future growth. Have 60 shops that previously closed at 6pm, now open until 9pm. Hope to get to c100 late openings by year end. Early days, but a good start given the trial is in its very early stages. Already had a sharply priced deal (£2 pizza slice and a drink) to encourage demand.

· Have been carrying on work on delivery, encouraging demand given they are doing it from shops that are trading in the day time.

· Distribution center in Wiltshire – work continues. Currently, anything south of there are being serviced by distribution centres further away. Should be operational by year end, and help take pressure off other DCs, as well as allow the company to expand its shops into the South of England.

· Some stock build pre potential Brexit issues, to ensure flow of goods. Same as they did in the run up to end of March.

Q&A

· Margin in quarter, has it been better year on year? Yes, has been positive as last year more soft drinks were sold in early part of Q3 (lower margin), whereas mix has been more favourable in Q3 19.

· Input costs - good visibility to the end of the year. Well bought forward on pork, took a price increase on June. Expect there will be more inflation next year. NLW: c5% increase in the next 5 years in terms of noise coming out of government. Pork ‘low single digit’ of cost base, one of the biggest areas.

· Delivery. c20 shops in various locations that trade conventionally, no new products in. Have bundled/presented some of the deals differently to make it more attractive. 60% of UK delivery market is after 6pm at night, but the fastest growing part of the market are other areas eg, breakfast and lunch. Greggs currently see peak in demand for final hour before breakfast closes (mid-morning). Average transaction value is c3x what is seen in the shop, people buying for more than one person. Now they are adding in more food in the evening, they are doing meal deals that apply to the evening only (ie post 4pm). Pizza meal deal is growing significantly, seeing how that goes into the evening. Will bundle sandwiches and potato wedges in the evening, so no new products, but bundling them differently.

· Strategic initiatives, what are they contributing to sales growth right now? They are not contributing to the current numbers, are very small this year. The same way as stretching day parts into breakfast, etc has been a driver in recent years the company hopes late day part will be a driver in future years.

· NLW – already pay younger workers the same rate.

· Hot food – much of this is third party rather than made by Greggs, but some of it is made in shops.

· What’s planned next in vegan after the success of the sausage roll? Want to produce a vegan version of the best-selling lines, but it’s not easy as they will only do it if it tastes good. 86% of purchases of vegan sausage rolls are not made by vegans, so needs to have broad appeal and not undermine quality of overall offer.

Valuation: based on FY20 Bloomberg consensus: PE 25.2x, EV/EBITDA 12.0x and Div yield 2.1%

11:13 am
BE11:13am

The only way to excuse Greggs, I thought, was that it was a necessity.

nightingale20201 I am surprised that there is no meaningful competition (vegan & plant-based) against GRG??
Kiwi-juice hello, any equity strategy piece published recently? I am looking for fresh ideas on what to buy, what country, what sector. Thx

If you have £4 in your pocket and 10 minutes before your shift starts, they'll do you a hot sandwich and some wedges to get you through the next nine hours.

XYZ9999 BAML on Airlines?
11:18 am

BE11:19am

At yesterday's close, Greggs was valued on 25.5x PE, 10.6x EV/EBITDA and 6.4% FCF yield for FY19E changing to 23.5x, 9.7x and 7.9% respectively for FY20E. Our 2050p target price remains based on the mid-point of the five-year average share price multiples.

VV75 Wendy's has tried and failed that 2 times in the past though, hence the lack of confidence.
BE11:19am

I wasn't kidding when I said an hour on Greggs.

11:19 am
undefined
BE11:20am

Okay, request wise .....

Hargreaves Lansdown PLC (HL.:LSE): Last: 2,020, down 59 (-2.84%), High: 2,085, Low: 2,017, Volume: 274.46k
Soundbuy Greggs and Wetherspoons - both fairly aggressive with closure of non-performing outlets/pubs......
11:21 am
BE11:21am

A number of factors here, including some start of quarter mark-to-market on the fund managers.

BE11:22am

But also Credit Suisse saying sell as part of a bigger thing on the sector.

chad_john That's why they're so successful though
BE11:22am

We initiate with an Underperform rating and £17.40 target. Our 2020-22 EPS forecasts are 6%-13% below consensus, and we find HL’s premium valuation difficult to support in the face of near-term revenue and earnings growth headwinds. We forecast only c.8% EPS growth FY20E, falling further to 5.5% FY21E, as slower growth in HL Funds revenue and a reversal in cash margin trends weigh on the revenue growth trajectory.

Soundbuy Yep..........
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Revenue headwinds
We forecast 11%-14% p.a. AuA growth FY19-22E, reflecting continued good net flow gathering capability for the group, and robust market outcomes (with HL helped by sterling weakness in the face of Brexit uncertainty).
Nonetheless, we forecast only about 7%-11% p.a. revenue growth over the same period, as we expect overall revenue margins to fall from 52bp FY19 to 47bp FY22E. This reflects a forecast shift in revenue mix rather than significant underlying fee margin pressure (for example in the platform fee margin).
HL Funds and Client cash yield contributed almost 30% of group revenue in FY19. Both are higher margin components: HL Funds revenue yield was 74bp, and client cash yield was 72bp. We forecast deteriorating growth trends for these two revenue components, which drives our forecast decline in overall revenue fee margin, and lower revenue growth.

BE11:23am

And of course there's the W word.

den It always makes me smile when they say '86% of purchases of vegan sausages are not made by vegans" Can someone explain how they know.
BE11:24am

HL’s response to the Treasury Select Committee2 included the information that 133,769 Hargreaves Lansdown clients have direct exposure to WEI, owning units worth £1.1bn. In total, 291,250 HL clients (£1.6bn assets) are directly or indirectly exposed. Indirectly exposed clients are those who own units in funds that have an underlying exposure to Woodford Equity Income fund, including the Hargreaves Lansdown Multi Manager range. HL disclosed it had received £41.1m platform fees since 2014 on its clients’ holdings in WEI.

Patience @den - because they only buy them once?
chad_john @den Reminds me of the old joke, "how do you know if someone is a vegan?" - "they've told you".
11:24 am
BE11:24am

The direct financial impact on HL from the loss of platform fees on the
WEI fund is limited, at ~0.45% of £1.6bn AuM = around £7m p.a. We see the greater immediate impact being from revenue headwinds in HL Funds fees (~0.75% p.a.) near term, reflecting net outflows related to these funds’ investments in WEI, and associated negative news flow. We do not assume significant longer term net flow impact from reputational damage at HL, but see this as a possibility, when combined with other factors.

VV75 @chad_john, exactly right
BE11:25am

So, it's mostly a slowing momentum and deteriorating quality story, along with a FinTech-Will-Eat-Us-All story.

BE11:25am

Panmure's also done a sector thing. They don't fancy HL either.

CryptoWhipto Thanks BE
11:26 am
BE11:26am

The industry is beset by well-versed issues including, but not limited to, revenue margin attrition, cost inflation, passive replication and increasing regulation. But the UK-listed sector is a poor proxy for the industry globally or even in the UK for that matter. We value longevity in client relationships, it is the key to long term delivery we believe. The sector offers opportunities for value, growth, income, large-, mid- and small-cap investors. Our overall favourite is Intermediate Capital.

BE11:27am

Analyst here is Phil Dobbin, ex of ....... Jefferies, is it?

Grouchmonkey @Forester me too. Dammit.
BE11:27am

And was at Shore for a while too, IIRC.

Soundbuy Revolution Bars RBG - looks a tad hmmmm.......
11:27 am
BE11:28am

Everyone knows the issues … – Globally the fund management industry is under revenue pressure from pricing and indexation. Costs are under pressure from regulation, product diversification and the internalisation of costs previously borne by clients. You could be forgiven for believing that there was no future. But the pressures are not new, nor necessarily accelerating.
 … so deal with them - The best defence is to provide fund investors with good risk-adjusted returns, and to do so over the long term. There is plenty of evidence that revenue margins can be robust if clients are happy. Longevity is the key to profitability, more so than a particular revenue margin. Costs must continue to come out, either a company’s own or someone else’s.

Soundbuy @den - perhaps they weigh the customers......
BE11:29am

Anyway. Upshot is that Hargreaves is too expensive.

BE11:29am

Hargreaves Lansdown has in our eyes confounded economic theory over the years by gaining market share despite never having a price leading product. We believe that this dynamic is explained by the breadth and quality of service offered. Customers on HL’s platform demonstrate strong persistency which along with its high DPS pay-out ratio helps to explain its high rating. We believe that the company is doing the ‘right thing’ in investing is its proposition across its client lifecycle. What we need to recognize however, is that we are now unlikely to see significant operational gearing. We can justify a DCF based share target price of c.1696p and at the current share price of 2077p, we rate the shares a Sell purely on valuation grounds.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Prefer ......

Plato the Cook Isn’t intermediate capital a very different business to HL?
BE11:30am

 Best for value – Standard Life Aberdeen (BUY) still has much work to do to deliver the benefits of its 2017 merger. Costs have been reduced materially but the benefits of the enhanced product range and revitalised distribution have, to date, been mitigated by outflows from legacy products. The market remains to be convinced of the strategy and the asset management business is currently valued at just three times estimated earnings after allowing for the value of listed associates.
Those associate stakes are being sold to take advantage of the undervaluation.
 Best for growth – Liontrust (BUY) has a simple model: deliver investment performance from active management, generate flows, manage costs and generate operational gearing. Organic growth has been supplemented by judicious acquisitions, leveraging the fixed overhead and increasing diversification. It reminds us of Jupiter’s approach before its tilt to Europe.
 Best in class – Intermediate Capital (BUY) is in the sweet spot of an asset class seeing material new business growth; near impossible to replicate on a passive basis; utilising closed-end funds of long tenure; with robust, and in some cases expanding, revenue margins; and with the scope for material operational gearing. We think fund raising will continue to surprise on the upside, as will the delivery of operating profit and hence dividends.

BE11:30am

And everything else is a hold.

den @soundbuy - v.good

BE11:45am

Renewi# (Buy, TP 60p) - Pre-close interims – In line
Trading since the last 11 July update has been in line with management expectations. Commercial: Momentum from price increases and cost synergies has more than offset lower paper prices, a slight slowdown in volumes and higher incineration gate fees – the AEB incinerator shutdown should have no material impact.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

(@Irish: I'd not disagree.)

BE11:45am

ATM: Soil tests have delivered a clean bill of health and the new dis-aggregating process is also progressing well, with currently limited capacity at present increasing soon to over 50% of ATM prior capacity – we would like but do not expect immediate regulatory clarity. Asset disposals: The sale of Reym and Canada has reduced our balance sheet debt estimate for FY20 to €480m. PPP: The Derby contract has now been terminated. Outlook: Management is becoming more confident of increasing production at ATM in FY20 (we exclude soil decontamination from all our forecasts).

BE11:45am

We maintain our forecasts for PBT/EPS for FY20/21/22E of €46.8/50.0/52.3m and 4.4/4.7/5.0c. With steady progress being made to a simpler future, we maintain our TP and recommendation.

Ferguson PLC (FERG:LSE): Last: 6,202, up 258 (+4.34%), High: 6,260, Low: 6,024, Volume: 108.00k

Q4 beats. Mostly on costs but also on share gains.

11:58 am
BE11:59am

Here's UBS.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Do the stupid public realise that Just Eat and Deliveroo will just push down the quality of already crap food.
BE11:59am

Q419 / FY19 result solid despite weak top-line growth
Q4 organic growth remained soft at +2.1% (UBSE +2.6%), a small deceleration from
Q3 of +2.7%. The US grew +3% (UBSE +4%), similar to Q3 of +3.3%. Q419E trading
profit (EBITA) came in at US$498m, up 10% y/y and 4%/6% ahead of UBSE/consensus.
This includes a US$7m one-off which would reduce this beat by c1.5%. Margins were marginally up in the US (+10bps), with solid improvement in the UK (+1.9ppt). On a FY19 basis, EBITA came in 1%/2% ahead of UBSE/consensus and EPS by c2%. Net debt was slightly lower at US$1.2bn (UBSE US$1.34bn) and puts net debt/EBITDA at 0.7x.
Outlook: US remains subdued; outlook for progress
Into the new financial year, US market growth remains flat, with Ferguson expecting to continue to outperform. The company points out that these trends are the same as in H219, when US organic growth was +3%. This is consistent with our forecast of +3% organic growth in FY20E for the US. Overall the group is guiding to "further good
progress". We note our forecast is for +2% EBITDA growth and consensus for +3%. We think guidance could imply a somewhat more optimistic outlook (FY19 EBITA growth was +7%) on earnings than is currently implied by consensus.
No update to corporate structure
There is no update to the statement issued in September, when the group announced a CEO succession, the planned demerger of the UK, and that it was considering its listing structure. With the group becoming a North American pure play, we think a re-listing in the US is becoming increasingly likely, although this would be subject to 75% shareholder approval.

BE12:00pm

And RBC

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

FY trading profit was slightly ahead at $1601m vs $1570m forecast (cons $1574m), with Q4 LFL organic growth slowing slightly to 2.1% (vs 2% forecast, and vs 2.7% in Q3). The US grew at 3.0% (vs 3.3% in Q3), whilst the UK (-0.3%) and Canada (-5.2%) were weak in Q4. The FY EBITA margin was ahead at 7.4% vs forecast 7.2%, with the US margin -20bp vs forecast -30bp. This was driven by a headcount reduction in the final months of the year. That said, restructuring costs were higher than expected at $91m, relating to branch closures and a US voluntary redundancy programme, whilst, central costs benefited from $7m one-off items. The statement says little in terms of outlook other than the US market is currently flat, although it expects to outperform. Overall, a muted outlook and it looks to us as if numbers have only been met by taking costs below the line. We would note, comparatives remain tough for the next couple of quarters and lead indicators remain mixed, with a US election also an uncertainty next year. We also don't see a UK demerger or listing change as necessarily creating value. For similar US exposure in the sector we prefer AHT - it has higher structural growth, less construction exposure and trades at a significant discount.

BE12:00pm

We like its market position, balance sheet and focus, but believe the share price has run too far. Current trading is muted and comparatives remain tough for the next couple of quarters. We also don't see a UK demerger or listing change as necessarily creating value. For similar US exposure in the sector we prefer AHT - it has higher structural growth, less construction exposure and trades at a significant discount.
